column5: message
List some key features in README

Document unsupported use cases of TokenSet#toArray

In cases where the TokenSet contains wildcard characters the behaviour
is undefined. Most likely an infinite loop will result, but I'm not
ruling out a black hole that devours the entire universe. You have been
warned ;)
Build version 2.3.6

Fix fuzzy string token set construction

A couple (more) bugs in how fuzzy string or edit distance based token
sets are constructed. This time there was issues with how fuzzyness at
the end of a string is matched.

A couple of fixes were applied; the change that was previously made to
fix this was applied to _all_ relevant parts of the function.
Additionally the way delete edits were addded to the token set was
slightly simplified. Finaly some redundant conditionals were removed to
hopefully simplify the logic.
Build version 2.3.5

Use Array.isArray to check if pipeline output is an array

TiddlyWiki (https://tiddlywiki.com), when run on Node, loads all of its
modules via Node's vm.runInContext.  This means that for my full text search
plugin (https://github.com/hoelzro/tw-full-text-search/), there is a
pipeline function loaded in its own context, separate from the context
lunr is loaded in.  This mismatch of contexts causes
"result instanceof Array" to always evaluate to false, which causes lunr
to break in further ways down the line.

Make sure fuzzy strings have fuzziness at the end

Fixes GH #375

Before, insertions were not made at the end of a fuzzy string for
token sets
Build version 2.3.4

Load inverted index into a prototype-less object

Fixes the issue where __proto__ is dropped from the inverted index
after a second deserializatoin

Test that __proto__ is indexed across two serializations

I found while using lunr that __proto__ can slip through the
serialization process if you're serializing an index that was
itself loaded from a serialized index - it might not be a bad idea
to make sure that serializing an index loaded from a JSON blob
serializes to the exact same JSON blob (well, forgiving things like
a change in the order of the keys)
Build version 2.3.3

Fix bug when performing wildcard prefix searches

A long forgotten TODO questioning some seemingly unused peice of logic
is _probably_ the cause. This commit removes code that added many
(hopefully) unnesecary edges to the token set as soon as a wildcard was
found.

All tests passed with that code removed. Extra tests have also been
added to try and trigger what I assume the previous code was defending
against.

I cannot remember _why_ this code was originally added, nor why I didn't
just remove it when I added the TODO questioning its usefulness. All
tests pass so _presumably_ its ok to remove.

The extra edges were introducing a, sometimes, significant performance
hit, particularly with leading wildcards, though presumably with any
wildcard search over a token of considerable length.
Build version 2.3.2

Fix term presence query parsing bug

Before adding term presence query terms only had modifiers in the suffix
position, e.g. 'term~1' or 'term^1'. Presence modifiers are in the
prefix position, e.g. '+term'. After seeing either a boost or edit
distance modifier the query parser did not anticipate seeing a presence
lexeme and so a query such as 'foo~1 +bar' would incorrectly cause a
parse error.

The fix involves properly handing a presence lexeme after seeing either
a boost or edit distance lexeme.
Build version 2.3.1
Add more words for the spellchecker to ignore

Fix bug in intersect/union on complete/emtpy sets

Both lunr.Set.complete and lunr.Set.empty are not 'real' sets but rather
objects that implement the interface of lunr.Set. The implementations of
intersect and union on lunr.Set always assumed that they would never be
passed either lunr.Set.complete nor lunr.Set.empty. This assumption was
wrong.

Performing a search with multiple required terms scoped by a field
when one term is not found causes lunr.Set.empty to be passed to
lunr.Set#intersect.

This throws an error because lunr.Set.empty does not include a list of
elements.

There may be other scenarios that also trigger this bug, as such both
lunr.Set#intersect and lunr.Set#union have been modified to handle both
lunr.Set.complete and lunr.Set.empty

Fix issue #279 (bug with Safari) (#361)

* Fix issue #279 (bug with Safari)

Calling any method defined on String.prototype on the expanded term
seems to force the string to be properly represented, fixing an issue
affecting Safari users.

See https://github.com/olivernn/lunr.js/issues/279

* fix issue #279 at the source, on TokenSet.prototype.toArray

it turns out that a specific string concatenation in
TokenSet.prototype.toArray sometimes results in a corrupted string in
Safari. It is fixed by calling any String.prototype method on it, which
forces the string to the correct representation.

The previous commit did the same, but this commit moves the fix closer
to the source of the problem. It could be applied exactly at the point
of the problematic concatenation, but that would result in some
unnecessary (if inexpensive) calls, so it is instead when pushing each
result string in the returned array.

* remove changes to generated distribution file

Update package.json version

Normally this would be done as part of the release but I messed it up :(
Build version 2.3.0

Add support for nested fields

When specifying a field to index an optional extractor function can be
defined. This function will be called when adding the document and
allows properties that are deeply nested within the object to be used as
fields. Previously only top level properties could be indexed.

Add yet more words for spellchecker to ignore

I'm not a fan of this linter, its dumb and its slow, but my spelling is
terrible and this is the price I have to pay.

Prevent problematic characters in field names

Field names can contain any characters _except_ forward slashes '/'.
This is because field names are combined with document refs in the index
with a forward slash. Document refs are allowed to contain forward
slashes and so if a field name _also_ contains forward slashes it is
difficult to split the combined FieldRef apart into its constituent
pieces.

Every approach that would allow field names to contain any characters
imposed a significant performance overhead on _every_ index, even those
that did not make use of field names containing forward slashes.

https://github.com/olivernn/lunr.js/issues/352

Add support for build-time field/doc boosts

Before Lunr 2.x build-time field boosts were supported, this was removed
in Lunr 2.x because query-time boosts were introduced. However
query-time boosts cannot cover all the use cases of build-time boosts
so build-time field boosts are being re-introduced as well as build-time
document boosts.

Modify lunr.Vector#similarity calculation

Removing otherVector.magnitude from the divisor allows similarity to
better accomodate boosted term scores.

This allows existing query-time boosts to be more effective as well as
paving the way for re-introducing build-time boosts.

The actual values returned when scoring will have changed as a result of
this modification. However the relative ranking of search results before
and after this change should not change. The score value in the search
results is an implementation detail used purely for sorting.

Remove redundant multiplication

clause.boost will always be a number and has a sensible default of 1.
Multiplying the boost by 1 is redundant. Removing this redundant
multiplication had a small, but measurable, positive impact on benchmark
results.

Upgrade dependencies

Upgrade Mocha to gain debug support and upgrade uglify-js due to a
vulnerability.
Clone options for multiple string terms in Query#term
Add link to scoring guide in search jsdoc
Build version 2.2.1
Update gitignore

Fix bug when using field scoped required terms

The correct behaviour when searching for a required term without field
scoping is that the term must appear in ANY of the fields. However the
previous implementation meant that a term must appear in ALL of the
fields.

Additionally there was a bug in how the required field matches were
combined which lead to more results being returned than should have.

Remove debugger from test

Accidently left it in there...

Fix shared examples in tests

It wasn't working how I thought it was, leading to some very weird
results, especially in the browser.
Expose test server on remote hosts

Add debug target

Uses mocha inspect-brk
Upgrade mocha
Build version 2.2.0

Update Index constructor JSDoc

fix JSDoc for the constructor of Index class

Add field metadata to tokens

When building and searching, tokens passing through the relevant
pipeline will have an additional entry in the metadata, fields.

At build time this will be the field in which the token was found, at
search time this will be the fields this term is going to be searched
in.

This additional entry in the token metadata will allow users to
customise their pipeline, performing different processing depending on
the field a specific token is from.

Add multi-term support to Query#term

Previously a single term could be passed to the Query#term method,
additionally this term needed to be a string. No tokenization is
performed by this method. The API was a bit cumbersome when dealing
with user entered queries, tokenization had to be done manually, and
then the results manually iterated over and used with Query#term.

This change improves matters in two ways:

* Lists of terms are supported
* A term can be anything that responds to `toString`

Together these two changes make it possible to directly use the
lunr.tokenizer when passing strings to Query#term.
BUild version 2.2.0-alpha.2

Stop calculating similarity score unnecessarily

In cases where we know a document/field is not going to make it into the
results due to a terms presence (either required or prohibited) there is
no point in calculating a similarity score.

This leads to a minor performance improvement for queries that contain
either required or prohibited terms.

Add support for negated queries

A negated query is one in which all terms have a prohibited presence.
Handling these queries requires some special handling. Specifically
empty match data should be created as well as extracting _all_ field
refs to construct the results.

Add lunr.Query#isNegated

A negated query is one in which _all_ terms have a presence of
prohibited. When executing a negated query some special handling is
required and this method is used to trigger that handling.

Add support for empty MatchData

In totally negated queries there will be no matches and therefore an
empty MatchData object is required for returning in the search results.

Ensure empty vectors have a similarity of 0

Previously calculating the similarity with an empty vector would give a
score of NaN. This might technically be correct but probably isn't very
useful. Instead we change this to zero.

Scoring empty vectors is a side effect of introducing totally negated
queries.
Build version 2.2.0-alpha.1
Fix some lint errors
Update documentation for term presence queries
Add presence queries to search tests
Add query string support for presence modifiers
Add tests for lunr.Set

Add initial implementation of term presence

Prohibited, required and optional presence modifiers returning expected
results in search tests.
Build version 2.1.6

Pipeline performance improvement for large fields (#329)

* Pipeline performance improvement for large fields

* Pipeline performance test
Build version 2.1.5
Fix broken links to .md files.
Fix matchData.metadata keys for multiple-term matches.

Fix docs target

Changing the location of the README broke the documentation target.
Build version 2.1.4

Switch from mdown to md for markdown file ext

NPM has stopped displaying the readme on the package page and suggest
switching to md file extension, for consistency lets do the other
markdown files as well.
Update version of jsdoc

Update doc and lint targets dependencies

Only lint and document the files that will end up as part of the build

Cache results of idf calculation during build

Generating vectors is the most time consuming aspect of building an
index, specifically the idf calculation. Before this change the inverse
document frequency of a term would be calculated more than once if that
term appeared in multiple documents/fields. This was not cached as it
was beleived that the cost of calculating the idf was cheap, however new
data shows that an improvement in build performance would be possible by
caching idf values.

https://github.com/olivernn/lunr.js/issues/305

Prevent duplicate inverted index lookups

If a query contains duplicate terms for a given field we only need to
retrieve the matching documents once. Before this change a duplicate
query term field combination would be looked up in the inverted index
multiple times.

This is especially a problem when constructing a query as recomended for
perfoming type ahead search. The combination of exact match, prefix
match and fuzzy match is able to produce multiple duplicate query terms.

This change keeps a cache of already seen term field combinations and
uses this cache to only lookup matching documents for that term field
combination once.

Add more focused method for combining match data

Additionally, several small adjustments to query code to get a bit more
performance.
Stop needlessly recreating field ref string
Add wildcard test matching 0 or more characters
Build version 2.1.3
Expose Builder.build()
Build version 2.1.2

Clone token metadata to prevent mutation

When creating instances of lunr.MatchData the token metadata must be
cloned to prevent mutation of the metadata stored in the inverted index.

Without cloning, combining match data instances for the same term can
lead to the original metadata in the inverted index from being mutated.
Build version 2.1.1

Use prototype free object for `fieldTerms` hash

Previously terms that collided with standard Object properties we breaking
the calculation of frequencies - leading to NaN scores for queries.

Update bower and component package definitions

Apparantly they are still a thing...
Build version 2.1.0
Update docs for wildcards and escape chars
Improve query parser error messages
Build version 2.1.0-alpha.2
Fix some spelling mistakes

Create a query vector per field for scoring

Previously a single query vector was created for use in scoring
documents against a query. This could lead to some incorrect results
when performing queries with boost specific to certain fields.

If a query term has different boost for different fields the approach of
using a single vector will mean that the same boost is used for both
fields.

Instead we create a vector per field, this prevents a boost from being
applied to terms in different fields.

Add support for escape sequence in query string

Before it was not possible to escape the reserverd characters when
performing a search using a query string. This allows searching for
literal reserved characters using lunr.Index#search. Using backslash "\"
as the escape character.
Build version 2.1.0-alpha.1

Add support for adding wildcards to clause term

Introduces a lunr.Query.wildcard property with flags for defining
whether to add leading or trailing wildcards to a clause term. Flags can
be combined to add leading and trailing wildcards.

The term is checked for existing wildcards to prevent double wildcards
and by default the wildcard property is set to none.

Split document vectors into field vectors

To be able to support accurate field based search the smallest unit of
data within the index needs to be the field, not the document. This
change changes lunr from being document centric to being field centric.

This means changing the stored vectors to be by document/field tuple,
rather than just by document.

Additionally, when querying, the query vector can be greatly simplified,
treating each query term as similarly important (plus any boosts). This
allows us to remove some of the index properties that were only present
to aid calculating query term weights.
Build version 2.0.4

Fix IDF calculation

Missing logarithm meant very common words were not being properly
normalised.
Build version 2.0.3

Add lunr.Vector#upsert method

Before lunr.Vector only supported insert, and this method would fail if
trying to insert a value with a duplicate index. When building the
document vectors this is the correct behaviour, however, for query
vectors there may be duplicate query terms in the query. Instead of
failing, the values should be combined.

In the future there should probably be some kind of query optimisation
that runs to execute queries in a smarter way, e.g. not querying for the
same term twice, but this is more complex than I want to tackle right
now.

Instead this change unblocks some current usecases for lunr and doesn't
close any doors to further query optimisations.
Build version 2.0.2

Reduce term score precision in vectors

This change reduces the number of decimal places used to represent the
score of a term within a document vector. Through testing this has been
seen to not have any impact to the relevance of the search results but
does lead to a ~15% size reduction when serialising indexes, before and
after compression with gzip.

Make separator used in lexing match tokeniser

Previously only a space " " was considered a term separator when lexing
and parsing a search string. This did not match the tokenisers idea of
what was considered a token separator. This lead to issues where it was
not possible to search for some terms within an index. Specifically a
document containing a hyphenated token, e.g. "foo-bar" could not be
searched for as the query parser would convert this to two separate
terms "foo" and "bar" where as in the index this would be a single term
"foo-bar".

This commit adds a property on the lunr.QueryLexer for the correct
separator to use, it currently points to lunr.tokenizer.separator so
that if a user changes the global separator for tokenising it will be
reflected when parsing queries. It may be required to make this more
configurable in the future, but for now this should suffice.
Build version 2.0.1

Use objects without prototypes in lieu of HashMap

Lunr makes heavy use of objects in place of a native HashMap. In most
cases this is fine, but can cause problems when the keys to be stored
clash with properties in Object.prototype.

This change swaps the instances where we check for the existance of a
key within an object to use an object without prototype, created using
Object.create.

This has some implications for support in old browsers, they would need
to use a library that provides a polyfil for this behaviour of
Object.create. Most browsers now seem to support this so I think it is a
trade off worth making.

Update README.mdown

Fix broken links
Build version 2.0.0
Add some missing documentation to lunr.Builder.

Remove old example app

It served us well over the last few years, but the example now lives at
https://olivernn.github.io/moonwalkers/
Update README.mdown

Build and upload docs as part of travis build

Docs are a build artifact, and the current documentation build produces
tons of artifacts. This commit removes the docs from the repository and
moves the building and deployment of the documentation to travis.
Remove accidental global from test
Build version 2.0.0-alpha.5

Fix bug that allowed extra entries in token sets.

TokenSet#toString is used to identify candidates during minimisation.
Previously this was a recursive function that incorporated the finality
of a TokenSet, its edges and the toString of all its children.

This lead to a bug where TokenSets were minimised incorrectly, leading
to extraneous entries in the TokenSet. When these were looked up in the
inverted index, there was no corresponding entry, leading to no method
errors.

By giving each token set an auto incrementing id we can be sure when we
are referring to the same TokenSet during minimsation.

This issue was detected in https://github.com/olivernn/lunr.js/issues/68
Build version 2.0.0-alpha.4

Ensure that query terms are lower case.

The index stores all tokens as lower case, this is handled by the
tokeniser. Queries are not passed through the tokeniser though, instead
they are parsed by the QueryParser.

In this change the QueryParser is modified to down case all query terms,
this leaves any up case fields untouched.

Before this change a search term that in upper case would result in no
matches, even if a document contained that term. This is especially
confusing if the original document had the term in upper case.
Build version 2.0.0-alpha.3

Add `use` method for applying plugins.

This is identical to the `use` method in previous versions of lunr.
Build version 2.0.0-alpha.2
Expose the version of lunr.

Yield builder to config function.

Fixes a regression from the previous version.
Build version 2.0.0-alpha.1

Remove empty message detail from QueryParseError.

When there are problems parsing a boost or edit distance from a query
the lexeme found is a zero length string. The previous error messages
for these errors tried to indicate what was found by the parser, a zero
length string is not useful in these cases.

Arguably the parsing/lexing process could provide what was found instead
of the expected numbers, this is a larger change though.

Change structure of MatchData metadata.

Before it was not possible to know which term some metadata was
associated to. With this change the metadata is collection of metadata
addressable by term and field, e.g. metadata[term][field][key].

Specifically without this it made highlighting matches difficult as the
positions were not in order, after this change matches are grouped by
term and field and therefore are always in order.

This might make it slightly more hardwork for consumers to use the data
but as common access patters arise convinience methods can be added.

Fix bug when combining match data objects

If a match was found in multiple fields the metadata object of the
MatchData class would not have a key for the other field being combined.
This change adds checks and ensures that matches across multiple fields
are supported.
Fix the test build.
Only build on recent versions of node.

Ignore term index when calculating IDF.

The terms index is stored in the posting for a term. This is a special
field in the posting and shouldn't be treated as a document field.
Remove build artifacts from version control.
Update travis build definition.

Replace homebrew static server with node-static.

The old server.js static file server has been around since almost the
beginning, but its time to move on...

Fix a lot of spelling mistakes.

I should really learn to spell :(

Add check for lunr version when deserialising.

There is no guarantee that an index serialised with one version of lunr
will correctly be de-serialised in another. Print a warning message in
these cases to help the user.

Ensure tokenization of arrays returns lunr.Token[].

This clears up a TODO that has been hanging around since the move to
lunr.Token over simple strings.
Remove redundant TODO.

Tweak scoring calculation.

A few subtle tweaks to the scoring calculation. Also, adding setters on
the builder for the tuning parameters to ensure that they are within the
correct range.

Remove while(true) when lexing digit runs.

By removing a while(true) and replacing it with a loop that has a
condition as its terminator there is a noticeable performance boost for
queries with modifiers.

Dry IDF calculation.

Centralise the calculation of inverse document frequency, a single
function is shared between the builder and the index.

This also stops storing the IDF in the inverted index. This stored value
was never actually being used. By removing it we get a slight speed up
in the builder as well as a noticeable speed up in searching. A small
amount of space will also be saved when serialising and keeping the
index in memory.

Add search pipeline.

A default search pipeline contains just a stemmer. When searching terms
are passed through the search pipeline and the resulting strings are
used for lookups in the token set.

Some terms will not be passed through the pipeline, primarily those
which contain a wildcard, but any term can bypass the pipeline by
setting the relevant option on the query term.
Adding documentation.
Add support for dumping and loading indexes

Improve performance of lunr.TokenSet.fromArray

Caches the string representation of a token set once we know it has been
finalised, prevents continually recalculating the value when it will
never change. This leads to an order of magnitude increase in
performance when creating a TokenSet from an array.

Replace for-in with Object.keys and for loop.

To avoid de-optmisiation of the function under V8 this change removes
the for-in loop. The inverted index is likely to enter hash mode with
enough terms added.

Update benchmark tests for latest version.

Old benchmark tests were no longer relevant, this adds perf tests for
the new objects in this version of lunr.

It also improves the runner and allows them to be run in node.

Add linting and fix lint errors.

Enforce code style and check fo some bugs and issues.

Remove lunr.SortedSet.

It is no longer being used and should have been removed before.
Replace Qunit with Mocha/Chai
Fix leaking globals.
Tests working in a browser.
Convert search tests to Mocha/Chai
Convert QueryParser test to mocha/chai.
Simpler Mocha reporter and remove colour.
Convert query lexer test to Mocha/Chai.
Convert match data test to mocha/chai.
Convert pipeline test to mocha/chai.
Convert trimmer test to mocha/chai.
Convert stopword filter test to mocha/chai.
Convert stemming test to mocha/chai.
Convert Vector test to mocha/chai.
Translate pipeline tests.
wip! start migrating test files to mocha
Add mocha and chai as dev dependencies.

Makefile fixes.

Start using the correct list of sources for this version.
Apply term boosts when performing a search.
Adding search tests.
Provide an easy way to search by a query string.

TokenSet can be created from a query clause.

Convinience function for creating a token set from the query clause,
takes into account any edit distance attached to the clause and
delegates to either the edit distance or plain string constructor.

Provide an interface for adding clauses to query.

Allows the parser to ensure the right fields are attached to each query,
and allows end users some more control also.
wip! working query parser.
WIP: first implementation of query lexer.
Tests for MatchData.

Remove some per-field data.

We are scoring the entire document all the time, so we only need
document vectors for the whole document, not each individual field. This
also simplifies the average length data and idf calculation.
Basis of runnng more complex queries.
Adding metadata about a token to inverse index.
Remove the use of arguments from tokenizer.
Storing token position and index.
Integrate lunr.Token into pipeline.
Add transpose support for fuzzy strings.

Add Levenshtein automaton to TokenSet.

Allows for 'fuzzy' searches by representing a set of tokens which are a
specified edit distance away from a given string. This token set can be
intersected against any other token set as before.

Currently the following edits are considered at unit cost:
* insertion
* deletion
* substitution
Out with the old, in with the new...
More hash like object iteration tweaks.

Prevent Builder#idf from being deoptimised.

Must not shadow a non local variable when using a for-in loop.

Performance tweaks for TokenSet#intersect.

More changes related to objects entering 'hash' mode and defeating V8s
optimisations. Iterating over these hash like objects is more performant
when using Object.keys and a for loop rather than the more vanilla
for-in loop.

Allow TokenSet#toString to be optimised by V8.

The token set object contains an object `edges` that is being used as a
hash. This prevents V8 from optimising the function [1]. Knowing that
the `edges` object is always 'hash like' we get all its keys using
Object.keys and iterate this list using a regular for loop.

Some quick benchmarks showed a small increase in performance from this,
but the function is now being optimised, which means that we should be
able to get 'free' performance improvements from V8, and possibly other
JavaScript engines, in the future.

[1]
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/24414809/iterating-through-javascript-hashtable-without-causing-optimization-loss

Small performance improvement in search method.

Only iterate over the matching document refs one less time.
Adding some tests for the builder object.
Add some tests for the token set object.
Rename FSA to TokenStore.
Fixes for the FSA object.

Change the way an FSA is created.

Convinience constructor for creating FSA from an Array. This delegates
the actual construction to the FSABuilder object.

Remove prototype search from the builder class.

This was only here whilst putting together the prototype of the index
builder, search will be a responsibility of the index class.
fix! fix a bug where idf was calculated to be NaN.

wip! inverted index does not contain ALL

Can also search by field.

Still need to clean things up quite a bit here though.

Refactor Vector implementation.

Instead of using a linked list we use a flat array where the odd
elements are the indexes and the even elements are the values.

This roughly halves the amount of space required for the vector,
sacrificing a very small amount of performance. The _very_ small
performance drop during calculating the dot product surprised me, I
would have thought it would have been quicker, calculating the magniture
is about twice as quick though with this implementation.
wip! almost at parity with 0.x branch
wip! New index is now searchable.
Add fsa storing the entire corpus terms.
wip! re-structuring the index building
wip! implementing basic search and scoring.
wip! calculating term weights in builder
wip! beginings of the builder.

Add lunr.Token

lunr.Token encapsulates a token, and its metadata, whilst it is passing
through the processing pipeline. A token can be modified, whilst
maintaining any metadata present. It can also be cloned when a token
needs to be expanded into multiple tokens.

Pipeline functions can expand tokens.

A pipeline function can expand a token into multiple tokens that will be
passed to following pipeline functions as regular tokens.
Build version 1.0.0

Remove incorrectly spelt lunr.tokenizer.separator.

This completes the deprecation started in release 0.7.2 introduced by
this commit c1686768f93ff73ebb08f82bc245e850face0554.
Add npm package install details.
Fix package.json version.
Build version 0.7.2

Fix bug when loading a serialised tokenizer.

Instead of loading the serialised tokenizer the setter property was
being set.

Upgrade PhantomJS.

Yes, the previous version was probably very old, but it worked. A fresh
install of the dependencies failed trying to install phantomjs. I don't
know how this happens, but it's pretty borked and I don't have time to
fix this now.

Instead upgrading to the next minor version resolves the problem.

Correct spelling of separator.

So, I cannot spell :(

Sadly this mispelling was in the public API for customising the
separator for the tokenizer. Backwards compatibility is retained by
keeping the misspelt property, but preferring the correctly spelt
separator property.

Integrations that make use of the old property will still work, but this
property is now deprecated and will be removed in the next major version
release. Customising the tokenizer should be done by setting the new
property - lunr.tokenizer.separator.

On the plus side maybe this will help me remember to spell separator
correctly from now on!
Build version 0.7.1
Specify the license when using jsdoc @license tag.
Build version 0.7.0
Update perf test fixtures.

Make tokenizer a property of an index.

Before this change the tokenizer was a global property of lunr, every
index would use the same tokenizer. It was possible to change the
tokenizer but not on a per index basis.

This change gives each instance of lunr.Index its own tokenzier,
defaulting to the existing lunr.tokenizer implementation. Each index can
change the tokenizer it uses without affecting any other index instance.

To ensure that indexes with custom tokenizers can be serialied and
de-serialised custom tokenizers can be regsitered in much the same way
as a custom text processing function is registered in lunr.Pipeline.

Improve the performance of Index.add.

The loops in Index.add can easily be called hundreds of thousands of times for
large documents. Larger documents can perform particularly badly[1] under
Chrome. Removing the usage of reduce and filter in favour of inline native for
loops can lead to a 20-30% performance increase in Chrome. Firefox also sees a
similar but much smaller impovement (~5%).

[1]: https://github.com/mkdocs/mkdocs/issues/859#issuecomment-192187096
Build version 0.6.0
Fix error message in release script.

Parameterise the tokenizer string seperator.

Make it easier to change the boundaries on which strings are split into
tokens.

Allow tokenization of arrays with null values.

If the array passed to the tokenizer contains some null or undefined
values the tokenizer should not explode. Instead an empty string should
be returned.

Add lunr.utils.asString function.

Delegates to `Object.prototype.toString` on all object except for null
and undefined which return an empty string. This behaviour is more
deisreable (to me) than having `undefined` and `null` converted to the
strings `"undefined"` and `"null"`

Move empty token filter from trimmer to pipeline.

The pipeline should ensure that the index gets clean data to work with,
in this case clean data means that no token should be empty. The
pipeline already included logic to filter out tokens that are undefined.
The pipeline function lunr.trimmer contained logic to exclude empty
strings.

The implementation of trimmer is not generic enough to be used with all
languages, specifically non latin character languages are not well
handled by the current implementation, and therefore in some cases users
choose to omit the trimmer from their pipeline. This can lead to issues
where empty tokens are introduced into the index.

This change moves the logic for filtering out empty tokens from the
trimmer to the pipeline itself, in the same way that the pipeline
removes undefined tokens, it now also removes empty tokens. With this
change the pipeline will guarantee that the index sees clean data,
regardless of whether the trimmer is part of the pipeline, it also
allows the trimmer function to be more focused on just trimming
whitespace.
Replaced array-like String access with ES3 compatible counterpart String.charAt(idx)

Add lunr.generateStopWordFilter function.

Provide a stopWordFiter generator that returns a pipeline compatible
function that can act as a stopWordFilter. This generator is used to
generate the default, English, stopWordFilter for lunr.

Ensure doc refs are not returned as strings.

Object properties are kept as strings so just using those for the doc
refs means all returned refs are strings. To return the same type of key
as was passed we must look at the ref property from the token store.
Build version 0.5.12

Trimmer should filter out empty tokens.

Adding empty tokens to the index will cause errors. This was prevented
by the stop word filter but in some use cases the stop word filter is
removed. In these cases the trimmer must ensure that it does not
introduce empty tokens.

Convert stop word filter from SortedSet to Object.

All stop words tests pass after this change. This change improves
performance of the stop word filter as demonstrated by the following
benchmarks:

* http://jsperf.com/lunr-stop-words-object/4
Build version 0.5.11

Use git describe to get the previous tag.

Tags do not sort numerically, so when the patch version is greater than
9 it messes up the checking of what has changed.

Add semicolon around unminified build.

Semicolons appear in the minified build but not as part of the
unminified build, this breaks some projects that use the unminified
build as part of their own build system. Fixes #162.

rename `handler` to `fn` in `event_emitter`/`index` comments

Before the total number of tokens was being used instead of the total

Build version 0.5.9
Merge branch 'pr/149'
issue 147, fix pipeline issue, add test cases

Cut recursion in SortedSet#indexOf & locationFor.

Reduce the overhead of recursive function calls from SortedSet#indexOf
and SortedSet#locationFor. On their own these changes make a
considerable performance gain, this improvement is more modest in the
context of the public Index#search and Index#add interface but is still
noticeable.

As well as the speed performance this change should also prevent these
methods blowing the stack on very large SortedSets.

fix the "make server" exception problem

Refactor `lunr.tokenizer` for speed

1. Use `String.prototype.trim`
2. Change the regex so that filtering out empty matches is not necessary
3. Call `toLowerCase` once instead of repeatedly in `map`

Removing the calls to `map` and `filter` results in pretty big speed
improvements (2X-4X), and probably (haven't tested it) lower memory
usage.

http://jsperf.com/stringsplitting

Add an "hour" value to the test date to prevent TZ issues

Making the hour `12` prevents daylight savings differences from
being a factor, since all that I know of happen in the very early
morning.

build version 0.4.5

Fix bug when generating idf for a token.

Stupid typo, should call the function with call, setting the context. As
it was the cache was never used! This resulted in a performance
regression when searching, since the cache would always be missed.
build version 0.4.4

Fix bug with tokens as obj properties in idf cache.

If a token was the same as a property name of the idf cache object then
the value of this property would be returned instead of the cached
value. Prefixing term with a '@' and using hasOwnProperty to guard
against this.

Combine src files with a ";"

Prevents issues when combined with other JavaScript files.
